intro: Daucus microcarpus, commonly known as the small-fruited parsley, is a member of the Apiaceae family. It is a herbaceous annual plant native to the western United States, particularly found in arid and semi-arid regions. The plant features finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in umbels. Its fruits are small, dry, and schizocarpic, typical of the carrot family. Daucus microcarpus is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in dry, sunny environments.
